Trial_Design.evidence: Patients diagnosed with grade III or IV haemorrhoids and anal fistulas at the Taipei Medical University Shuang-Ho Hospital, Taiwan, between 2022 and 2023, were enrolled in a randomized clinical study

Participants.evidence: Patients diagnosed with grade III or IV haemorrhoids and anal fistulas at the Taipei Medical University Shuang-Ho Hospital, Taiwan

Intervention.evidence: comparing the use of preoperative enema (intervention) versus no preoperative enema (control)

Objective.evidence: The objective of this study was to evaluate the efficacy and benefits of preoperative enemas in anal surgical procedures.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome measures included postoperative visual analogue scale scores and analgesic usage from postoperative day 0 to day 7.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 266 patients were enrolled in this study, with 133 allocated to the enema group and 133 to the control group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: the mean(s.d.) visual analogue scale score was significantly higher in the control group than in the enema group on day 2 (5.69(2.14) versus 3.77(2.45), P = 0.021), day 3 (5.85(2.61) versus 3.92(2.73), P = 0.042) and day 4 (5.23(2.55) versus 3.42(2.18), P = 0.027).

Harms.evidence: postoperative complications, including surgical site infection, postoperative bleeding and urinary retention.
